Their website:
 http://www.iconoclast-texas.com/
 
 Don't forget your paperweight:
 http://www.iconoclast-texas.com/ICONe-ADS/crawpaperweight.htm
 
 Their Kerry endorsement:
 http://www.iconoclast-texas.com/Columns/Editorial/editorial39.htm
 

 The publishers of The Iconoclast endorsed Bush four years ago, based on the things he promised, not on this smoke-screened agenda.
 Today, we are endorsing his opponent, John Kerry, based not only on the things that Bush has delivered, but also on the vision of a return to normality that Kerry says our country needs.
 Four items trouble us the most about the Bush administration: his initiatives to disable the Social Security system, the deteriorating state of the American economy, a dangerous shift away from the basic freedoms established by our founding fathers, and his continuous mistakes regarding terrorism and Iraq.

 
 
The Iconoclast, the President's hometown newspaper, took Bush on his word and editorialized in favor of the invasion. The newspaper's publisher promoted Bush and the invasion of Iraq to Londoners in a BBC interview during the time that the administration was wooing the support of Prime Minister Tony Blair.
 Again, he let us down.
 We presumed the President had solid proof of the existence of these weapons, what and where they were, even as the search continued. Otherwise, our troops would be in much greater danger and the premise for a hurried-up invasion would be moot, allowing more time to solicit assistance from our allies.
 Instead we were duped into following yet another privileged agenda.
 Now he argues unconvincingly that Iraq was providing safe harbor to terrorists, his new key justification for the invasion. It is like arguing that America provided safe harbor to terrorists leading to 9/11.

 
 
When examined based on all the facts, Kerry's voting record is enviable and echoes that of many Bush allies who are aghast at how the Bush administration has destroyed the American economy. Compared to Bush on economic issues, Kerry would be an arch-conservative, providing for Americans first. He has what it takes to right our wronged economy.

 
 
The re-election of George W. Bush would be a mandate to continue on our present course of chaos. We cannot afford to double the debt that we already have. We need to be moving in the opposite direction.
 John Kerry has 30 years of experience looking out for the American people and can navigate our country back to prosperity and re-instill in America the dignity she so craves and deserves. He has served us well as a highly decorated Vietnam veteran and has had a successful career as a district attorney, lieutenant governor, and senator.
 Kerry has a positive vision for America, plus the proven intelligence, good sense, and guts to make it happen.
 That's why The Iconoclast urges Texans not to rate the candidate by his hometown or even his political party, but instead by where he intends to take the country.
 The Iconoclast wholeheartedly endorses John Kerry.

Crawford mayor is Kerry supporter
 
 BY GROMER JEFFERS JR.
 
 The Dallas Morning News
 
 (KRT) - Crawford may be the heart of Bush country, but the town's mayor says John Kerry is the best choice for president.
 
 "I don't see where I'm better off than I was four years ago," Robert Campbell said Tuesday. "I don't see where the city is any better off."
 
 The Kerry campaign recently listed Campbell as one of 100 black mayors around the country - seven of them Texans - who support the Massachusetts senator over President Bush. But the campaign has not focused particular attention on the endorsement.
 
 With his sprawling ranch near Crawford, Bush is the area's most famous resident. Tourists flood the Central Texas city's tiny downtown on weekends to purchase Bush memorabilia and eat the Presidential cheeseburger basket at the Coffee Station, the restaurant that Bush occasionally visits while on vacation.
 
 Campbell, a Democrat who has been mayor since 1999, said he's met Bush once but doesn't feel inclined to support the former Texas governor. He voted for Al Gore in 2000.
 
 "I would say the city has a mix of Bush and Kerry supporters," he said. "The Kerry supporters feel like Bush has not delivered on his promises."
 
 Some Texas Republicans took the endorsement in stride.
 
 "You will find a few Kerry supporters in Texas," said Victor Carrillo, chairman of the Texas Railroad Commission. "But the majority of Texans support President Bush."
 
 Campbell says he's not worried about a backlash among his constituents.
 
 "I have the right to vote for who I want to be president," he said. "If some people around here don't like it, they can vote for someone else for mayor."

 Does it concern you that GWB is the spokesperson for the Republican Party? And I mean that in all seriousness. I don't ask it as a rhetorical or smart alec question. If you had your druthers, and the Republicans could do the primaries all over again from 4 years ago, would he be the choice?
 
 I ask because he's not done any favors for the phrase "conservative". There was a time, not that long ago, when "conservative" was mentally connected with old fashioned right and wrong mom and dad taught values. Now that word is more easily connected with terribly radical extreme right wing ideals. When I flip through the cable channels - and past some self-serving evangalist with his 1-800 number for donations - my mind sees GWB. When he speaks, I see air conditioned dog houses and whoever that one guy was that was caught in the motel and then on the TV crying that he'd sinned. That's the category I put him in. Not main stream religion.
 
 Personally, I guess I was always a moderate tending toward Republican. I've voted for way more Republicans than Democrats over the years. But since the Republicans have taken on this new face, I've been forced away from them. I can't find any single overriding issue or value that he touts that can allow me to overlook the big picture.
 
 With me, it's personal. It's GWB's facial expressions. It's his mannerisms. It's his words - or lack of them. His inability to comfortably articulate a story or a point. I see what I saw in my 14 year olds when they were trying to put one over on me.
 
 Has he been good for the party? Has he been good for the ideals? Has he openly brought out ideals that would have been more successfully achieved in the background? Will the portion of the population that has been made uncomfortable by him, personally, be an albatrose around the neck of the Republicans for years to come? GWB would have been easily elected had he been just a little more low key. Has he been a good ambassador for the Republican Party?

 Your emissions test is probably similar to mine. Virtually ALL cars are tested in my area however. (1968 & newer) 70's and 80's cars have a tough time here. 80% to 90% of the people have 90's and newer cars, and find it no problem. That's the way it's set up. It was experimented with in one or two carefully selected areas of the U.S. years ago, and those residents reactions were measured, and used to project reactions in other areas. Most people feel a slight sense of pride that their car passes, just enough to make them shrug off the fee. 
 
 It's a problem with small businesses that have older service vehicles that they wouldn't otherwise need to replace (plumbers, contractors etc.) It's a problem with older, retired people who keep an older car because they don't need it that often. Teenagers with their first car, trying to support it on an afterschool job - they're probably the ones who it affects most. It may make the difference if they can even have a car. In my area, there are no public announcements being made about it's effectiveness - no sign of before and after measurements being taken to show cleaner air. Probably because it's making no difference, other than to send millions of Ky. dollars to the California company doing the testing. 
 
 The bottom line is, it's an intrusive big government program, endorsed by Democrats far more than Republicans. The type of thing GWB doesn't show an interest in.

 Now we're in to child raising theories. I've raised 2 very successful sons and I had very strict rules on how much they were ALLOWED to work. As the parent, with the wisdom of years, they were not allowed to buy a junk heap of a car that was going to eat up more money than their minimum wage job could pay. Actually, they borrowed their vehicles from us. Also, I did a savings matching program with them. They were charged with the responsibility of saving $5000 by the end of their freshman year in college. If they were successful, I promised to match it. They both were - and their first car cost $10,000. I taught them to save - then buy. I taught them about long term goals and self control. That's a lot to learn for a 16 year old. That $10,000 car took them through the rest of college and to their first real job. Novel theory isn't it. It worked. They had their budgets and they had their savings accounts. And they learned the value of a dollar and thinking before they spent. They learned exactly what I wanted them to learn. My sons had plenty of desire and incentive to succeed. But it came from me - not McDonalds.

When it comes to topics like emissions, pollution, conservation, and recycling, I feel there has to be a higher power to help "regulate" their enforcement because I think human beings tend to be selfish and short-sighted in general. I'm not an advocate of governmental intervention as a rule, but I don't know how else to monitor these issues. If left to the private sector, monetary gain would always win out over the future well being of mankind. The argument on air pollution may minimize our effects on the air quality comparative to nature's, but it would be hard for anyone to deny we're responsible for all the damage to our water systems. In addition, it's common knowledge that fossil fuels are for the most part non-renewable, yet we have spent the last 10 years building the largest, most inefficient vehicles that are unquestionably depleting the supply of crude oil at an exponential rate. As George said, sooner or later simple economics is the best form of regulation: as gas gets more and more expensive, people will be forced to look for more efficient alternatives. Not because they're concerned about their children having oil, simply because they are financially forced to.

You (and the government) are free to label old cars junk heaps, and control their use in your own life, but not in others lives. When you argue that others use of them DOES affect your life in having to share the road with them, look at them, smell their stinky exhaust etc. then it's clear that you're arguing against freedom. Freedom does have a price.
marc9000

When it comes to topics like emissions, pollution, conservation, and recycling, I feel there has to be a higher power to help "regulate" their enforcement because I think human beings tend to be selfish and short-sighted in general. I'm not an advocate of governmental intervention as a rule, but I don't know how else to monitor these issues. If left to the private sector, monetary gain would always win out over the future well being of mankind. The argument on air pollution may minimize our effects on the air quality comparative to nature's, but it would be hard for anyone to deny we're responsible for all the damage to our water systems. In addition, it's common knowledge that fossil fuels are for the most part non-renewable, yet we have spent the last 10 years building the largest, most inefficient vehicles that are unquestionably depleting the supply of crude oil at an exponential rate. As George said, sooner or later simple economics is the best form of regulation: as gas gets more and more expensive, people will be forced to look for more efficient alternatives. Not because they're concerned about their children having oil, simply because they are financially forced to.

 
 As an entire group, I think human beings are less selfish and short sighted than the higher power.
jskufan

As an entire group, I think human beings are less selfish and short sighted than the higher power.

 
 I think it's ironic that you're so uncomfortable with the "government" protecting you from polution yet when they've made decisions on protecting you from terrorists and Saddam Hussien, you can't compliment them enough. If you're willing to trust them with your personal safety, and that of your families, why are you so skeptical when they want to keep your air clean. It seems a little inconsistent.

 I worked at Mcdonalds, and I rode a bike to work. Cheaper than a car, no gas, no emissions, no insurance, and you get your exercise too :) 
 
 It is possible to work without owning a "junk heap" which will only consume your limited wages.

Thanks for asking!! :) It's perfectly consistent with the CONSTITUTION. Our government has the authority to deal with foreign nations, because individuals can't do it. Individuals CAN run their own lives.

 
 Marc, I also agree the government exists for the purpose of protecting the citizens from foreign as well as internal attacks (crime). Other than maintaining infrastructure, I wouldn't give them much else if I had my way. I don't think they necessarily have everyone's best interest in mind when it comes to regulating resources and pollution, but, call me skeptical, I don't trust MOST people to do the right thing by themselves when it comes to preserving our planet. I don't know what the answer is, but for now it appears to be letting the people we supposedly elected, because they shared our values, look out for our best interest??? I know, I know, it sounds awfully Liberal but I'm open to suggestions! ;)

 I understand, the guys with the hot cars get the chicks! emoticon_xgood

And Happy Birthday to you too. :)

Happy birthday to both of you!! Marc, if I'd have known it was your birthday, I would have filtered out all the sarcasm from my posts till tomorrow! :p
georged

sooner or later simple economics is the best form of regulation: as gas gets more and more expensive, people will be forced to look for more efficient alternatives. Not because they're concerned about their children having oil, simply because they are financially forced to.

 
 I read a report from the automotive industry last spring that manufacturers have positioned themselves to continue production of SUVs and light P/U trucks in their current, fuel inefficient configuration for at least the next three years. They're basing that on on the public being able to absorb eventual fuel costs of $4/gallon and no downward trend in the economy. As those vehicle models are all that's holding US manufacturers together, I guess, given their financial position, they have to take an optomistic view of the future.
kickin50

What we already know? How do we "know" it - because the government told us? The government that you don't trust?

 
 No. Because we can see the difference and smell the difference. While our 5 senses aren't the last word, they can be trusted that far.
 
 
 
Waste storage and disposal, wetlands, endangered species, etc.

 
 So you want to start a garbage dump? You want to buy a swamp and drain it? I really don't get what you're saying.
 
 
 
My main point was how I don't see how you can consider something free enterprise when it starts not by market forces, but by a government command.

 
 The two can overlap and coexist. Example: Energy consumption is on the front of a new refrigerator. It may well play a part in consumer choices. If the government can nudge an inventor in giving me better choices, I'm good with that.
 
 
 
Sadly, most children don't have a father as involved, as good as you. Some teens don't have a father at all. McDonnalds may be the only way for some - a "junk heap" may be the only way for some. You (and the government) are free to label old cars junk heaps, and control their use in your own life, but not in others lives.

 
 This isn't about teen drivers, is it. There's no logic in having kids spend what little they can earn at a minimum wage job on a car that's in poor repair. Their money will be going out the left hand as fast as in comes in the right hand. It's a junk heap when it's in poor repair. Not when it's old. Not when it's unsightly. I own an old car. It's never failed to pass emmissions. It's not even close to the limit. Like I said $20 and 10 minutes every other year. Why object?
 
 and I'm a mother.
marc9000

Happy birthday to both of you!! Marc, if I'd have known it was your birthday, I would have filtered out all the sarcasm from my posts till tomorrow! :p

 
 Not a problem, you're a good debater! emoticon_xgood

It's never failed to pass emmissions. It's not even close to the limit. Like I said $20 and 10 minutes every other year. Why object?
 
 and I'm a mother.

 
 Here in the Kansas City area, vehicle owners on the Missouri side have to get their vehicles inspected. From what I understand, they inspect the entire vehicle for "road worthiness". They look at tread depth on tires, windshield cracks, and many other items that dictate whether a vehicle is safe to drive on the road. As an individual that takes care of his vehicle voluntarily, it's somewhat comforting to know that the car next to me has brakes and four good tires. I realize this could cause financial hardship for some, but do we really want cars on the road that shouldn't be, just because their owners can't afford to keep them safe?
marc9000

No. Because we can see the difference and smell the difference. While our 5 senses aren't the last word, they can be trusted that far. 

 
 I think they should be the last word. Action taken about pollution can be done with phone calls to politicians and VOTES. You trust government more than I do.
 
 
 
 
 
So you want to start a garbage dump? You want to buy a swamp and drain it? I really don't get what you're saying. 

 
 I have a friend with a farm. A hollow in a remote area of his farm, not near any borders, he made it a garbage dump. His father-in-law got mad at him for something unrelated, reported his land use to the EPA, and they moved in and gave him costly orders about its "clean up". There are many instances where landowners are denied their desired use of their own property in the name of endangered species and wetlands, and not being compensated for it, as required by the fifth amendment. It's not being reported on the news much, but that doesn't mean it isn't happening.
 
 
 
 
 
The two can overlap and coexist. Example: Energy consumption is on the front of a new refrigerator. It may well play a part in consumer choices. If the government can nudge an inventor in giving me better choices, I'm good with that.

 
 An energy consumption tag does not compare to a complex emission test of old cars. The existance of energy consumption tags can easily be determined by market forces.
 
 
 
 
 
This isn't about teen drivers, is it. There's no logic in having kids spend what little they can earn at a minimum wage job on a car that's in poor repair. Their money will be going out the left hand as fast as in comes in the right hand. It's a junk heap when it's in poor repair. Not when it's old. Not when it's unsightly. I own an old car. It's never failed to pass emmissions. It's not even close to the limit. Like I said $20 and 10 minutes every other year. Why object? 

 
 An INDIVIDUAL is the only one qualified to determine what is "logical" in how they work and what they buy. You're making blanket statements about other peoples choices, as if you are superior.
 
 I own an old pickup truck. It's 33 years old and looks like new. You can almost see the jealous little wimps at the testing station elbow each other and smile when they see me coming. (this one fails haha) It takes me HOURS of running here and there and signing papers to get a waiver on it. I think vehicles like that automatically fail. You undoubtedly think that all the testers do is operate the machines - the machines do the testing. Again, you trust the government far, far more than I do.
 
 
and I'm a mother.

 
 sorry emoticon_frazzled
marc9000

Here in the Kansas City area, vehicle owners on the Missouri side have to get their vehicles inspected. From what I understand, they inspect the entire vehicle for "road worthiness". They look at tread depth on tires, windshield cracks, and many other items that dictate whether a vehicle is safe to drive on the road. As an individual that takes care of his vehicle voluntarily, it's somewhat comforting to know that the car next to me has brakes and four good tires. I realize this could cause financial hardship for some, but do we really want cars on the road that shouldn't be, just because their owners can't afford to keep them safe?

 
 They were doing that here 30 years ago, and it soon disapeared. The "safety inspection" thing seems to come and go. Statistics clearly show that "unsafe vehicles" are seldom the cause of serious accidents. Most people have enough sense not to risk their own lives in a dangerous vehicle. Police usually (if not always) have the authority to ticket and tow any unsafe vehicle they pull over. They certainly do with heavy trucks, and I support that. That should be enough.
jskufan

I have a friend with a farm. A hollow in a remote area of his farm, not near any borders, he made it a garbage dump. His father-in-law got mad at him for something unrelated, reported his land use to the EPA, and they moved in and gave him costly orders about its "clean up". There are many instances where landowners are denied their desired use of their own property in the name of endangered species and wetlands, and not being compensated for it, as required by the fifth amendment. It's not being reported on the news much, but that doesn't mean it isn't happening.
 
 

 
 Sorry to horn in on this discussion, but I wanted to comment here. When your actions have the possibility of affecting others, you are subject to the rules that are designed to protect the innocent "masses". The problem with someone establishing a "garbage dump" on private property is the danger to surrounding individuals due to hazardous materials being carelessly dumped. If your friend dumped chemicals that leached through the soil and found their way into the community water table he would be placing his neighbors at risk. People don't want to live near landfills when their run professionally, they certainly don't want to when they're not. As a landowner, you're entitled to enjoy your investment, as long as your enjoyment doesn't infringe on others.
jskufan

They were doing that here 30 years ago, and it soon disapeared. The "safety inspection" thing seems to come and go. Statistics clearly show that "unsafe vehicles" are seldom the cause of serious accidents. Most people have enough sense not to risk their own lives in a dangerous vehicle. Police usually (if not always) have the authority to ticket and tow any unsafe vehicle they pull over. They certainly do with heavy trucks, and I support that. That should be enough.

 
 I would agree that police have the continual ability to remove unsafe vehicles from the roadways. In addition, a vehicle's condition can change dramatically in between the annual inspection, so there's no guarantee it's safe in the interim. Lastly, I guess our famous "legal system" is always available as a deterrent for those that want to push the lawsuit envelope. I license 4 heavy trucks in Missouri and we are always under the scrutiny of Missouri DOT.

marc9000

Don't you get a paper print out of the results? My sister owns a 1970 something Buick whatever. Burnt orange. And it doesn't look like new. Not visually pleasing. Hers passes every time.

 
 Yes we get a print out, and I don't really believe that the workers have the power to alter it. But I believe there are quotas - too many cars pass and there are political problems, too many cars fail and there are political problems. My truck barely fails, and I only drive it about 2000 miles a year, and that's not taken into account at all. Many cars that barely pass are driven 10,000 or more miles a year, and pollute far more than my truck. There's no way to make it fair. The fourth amendment has the phrases "probable cause" and "particularly describing". The founding fathers saw all encompassing searches in Europe, and they knew how tyrannical and unfair they can be.
